stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on the AI, animations, and camera for the 'Morkmar' oil boss. Key activities included debugging a major animation bug, implementing a wave attack, and discussing core design philosophies prompted by chat, particularly regarding player expectations for 100% completion in ROM hacks.

development_findings.summary: Kaze spent a significant amount of time debugging boss behavior before realizing he was editing the code for a different, non-boss object, a classic and relatable developer mistake.
development_findings.quote: I know what I did wrong. And I used the oil block instead of the oil block boss. No wonder it didn't work. I wasn't even editing the relevant code.

development_findings.summary: An attempt to integrate new, supposedly faster code from a contributor named 'Silas' resulted in animations being locked to 30 FPS, forcing Kaze to revert to a previous version.
Kaze articulated a core design principle of avoiding mechanics that force a player to exit a level and return later, citing this as the reason for removing 100-coin stars.
development_findings.quote: I never want the player to be in a level and then feel like, oh, I should leave this level and come back with a different set of equipment.

development_findings.summary: Kaze identified a key design constraint for ROM hacks: the community's expectation of 100% completion discourages the inclusion of extremely difficult or obscure optional content.
development_findings.quote: The player's expectation is that they can easily 100% the game... We can't put hard challenges without people complaining. We can't put super secret hidden stuff without people complaining. And I think that really takes away a lot of design space.

development_findings.summary: A discussion about an adaptable difficulty system led to the idea of findable 'perks' in the overworld that grant a single bonus, like 'no void out'. Kaze rejected a full RPG-style badge system as 'too much' for Mario 64.
Kaze implemented a lock-on camera for the Morkmar boss fight and dynamically adjusted its vertical angle based on Mario's distance to keep the boss visible and improve playability.
An idea for a final challenge was deemed impractical because the associated music was a 5MB WAV file, which is too large for the ROM's space constraints and would need to be converted to MIDI.

context_findings.summary: Kaze shared his core philosophy on processing community feedback, stating that while player feelings (e.g., frustration) are valid and must be addressed, their proposed reasons or solutions are often not.
context_findings.quote: What people feel, in a way, is real. You can't change that fact. But their reasoning is most of the time stupid. You should just ignore people's reasoning. But you can never really ignore people's feeling.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expressed a feeling of personal and professional growth, stating he feels he's rapidly improving in his skills.
context_findings.quote: Recently I feel like I have been evolving. I'm just getting so much better at everything for some reason.

context_findings.summary: Kaze revealed personal details about attending a wedding with his wife Zeina, expressing his dislike for such social events.
context_findings.quote: I hate weddings. It's gonna be awful. I wish I could just bring my DS like a little child and play my DS on there.

context_findings.summary: Kaze showed off a plushie he sewed by hand as a wedding gift, demonstrating a creative skill outside of game development and pride in his physical craftwork.
context_findings.quote: I worked very hard on this all week. My hands were in pain. But this right here is our little wedding present to my friends... I finally learned how to use a sewing machine too. I almost don't want to give him away.

context_findings.summary: Kaze criticized the famous Quake fast inverse square root algorithm, stating that its optimization was incomplete because it only addressed one of the three constants used.

biobak.summary: Biobak was credited with the idea for Morkmar, the oil boss, to have metal teeth, which Kaze praised as a 'very good idea'.
Biobak gave live feedback on the boss's attack animation, suggesting it should dip down more at the start.

zeina.summary: Zeina offered to do animation work for the project, confirming her role as a contributor beyond being Kaze's spouse.
Zeina playfully corrected Kaze's story about bad wedding food, revealing his picky eating habits and showcasing their lighthearted dynamic on stream.
zeina.quote: Chat, let me clarify, it was strawberry shortcake. And he hates anything that isn't chocolate cake.

zeina.summary: Zeina and Kaze had a playful exchange where she tried to embarrass him on stream, highlighting their close and humorous personal relationship.
zeina.quote: What you call me that live on stream, yes, what the fuck... God, damn it. Love you. Bye. Bye.

key_stories.title: The 100% Completion Dilemma
key_stories.summary: Kaze grappled with the design limitations imposed by the ROM hacking community's expectation of 100% completion. After confirming his theory with a live poll, he began brainstorming a 'perk' system as a way to introduce variable difficulty without alienating players.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze realized that the player expectation to 100% ROM hacks severely limits his ability to add extremely difficult or well-hidden optional content, which he feels is a valuable part of game design.
key_stories.process: Kaze reflected on negative feedback for difficult optional 'S-Ranks' in another hack, articulated his philosophy on player feedback, and then polled his live audience to confirm his hypothesis about completionist expectations.
key_stories.outcome: After running a poll that confirmed his suspicion, Kaze began exploring alternative systems, like single, findable 'perks' in the overworld, to offer optional difficulty adjustments without creating content that feels unfairly required for 100% completion.
key_stories.key_quote: My philosophy is, what people feel, in a way, is real. But their reasoning is most of the time stupid. You should just ignore people's reasoning. But you can never really ignore people's feeling.

key_stories.title: The Phantom Bug
key_stories.summary: Kaze was stumped by a bug where his code changes had no effect on the boss's behavior. After a frustrating period of debugging, he realized he was editing the wrong source file entirely, a simple but profound mistake that immediately solved the issue.
key_stories.challenge: While programming a boss's attack patterns, Kaze's code changes were having no effect on the game, and he couldn't figure out why the boss wasn't behaving as intended.
key_stories.process: Kaze spent considerable time tweaking animation code, movement logic, and rotation values, growing increasingly frustrated as nothing changed. He re-read his code multiple times before having a sudden epiphany about the filename.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze had a sudden realization that he was mistakenly editing the source file for a generic 'oil block' enemy instead of the unique 'oil block boss' object. Once he corrected the file, his changes worked immediately and he could proceed with development.
key_stories.key_quote: I know what I did wrong. And I used the oil block instead of the oil block boss. No wonder it didn't work. I wasn't even editing the relevant code.
